hints_html:
Remember that

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle e^{ix} = \cos(x) + i\sin(x)\end{aligned}\]

for any x. You can use this to decompose the solution into its real and imaginary parts. Since no imaginary component can be expressed in terms of the real components, the real and imaginary components can be used as a basis for the general solution.
hints_latex:
Remember that

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle e^{ix} = \cos(x) + i\sin(x)
\end{align*} for any x. You can use
this to decompose the solution into its real and imaginary parts. Since
no imaginary component can be expressed in terms of the real components,
the real and imaginary components can be used as a basis for the general
solution.
hints_raw:
Remember that
:<math>
\displaystyle e^{ix} = \cos(x) + i\sin(x)
</math>
for any x. You can use this to decompose the solution into its real and imaginary parts. Since no imaginary component can be expressed in terms of the real components, the real and imaginary components can be used as a basis for the general solution.
question: 8 (c)
sols_html:
The complex solution \(\vec{\mathbf{z}}(t)\) that we found in (a) and (b) is

\[\begin{aligned} \vec{\mathbf{z}}(t) &= e^{-t}e^{2ti}\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -i \end{pmatrix} \\ &= e^{-t}(\cos 2t + i\sin 2t)\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -i \end{pmatrix} \\ &= e^{-t}\begin{pmatrix}\cos 2t \\ \sin 2t\end{pmatrix} + ie^{-t}\begin{pmatrix} \sin 2t \\ -\cos 2t\end{pmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

From this we can read off the real-valued form as

\[\begin{aligned} \vec{\mathbf{x}}(t) = C_1 e^{-t}\begin{pmatrix}\cos 2t \\ \sin 2t\end{pmatrix} + C_2 e^{-t}\begin{pmatrix} \sin 2t \\ -\cos 2t\end{pmatrix}\end{aligned}\]
statement_html:
Consider the 2 x 2 system of differential equations

\[\begin{aligned} \mathbf{x}'(t)=\begin{bmatrix} -1 & -2\\ 2 & -1 \end{bmatrix} \mathbf{x}(t)\end{aligned}\]

where \(\mathbf{x}(t)=\begin{bmatrix}x_1(t)\\x_2(t)\end{bmatrix}\) is the vector of unknown functions.

Based on the results in (a) and (b), write down the general solution in real-valued form.
statement_latex:
Consider the 2 x 2 system of differential equations

\begin{align*}
\mathbf{x}'(t)=\begin{bmatrix}
-1  &  -2\\
2  &  -1
\end{bmatrix} \mathbf{x}(t)
\end{align*}

where $\mathbf{x}(t)=\begin{bmatrix}x_1(t)\\x_2(t)\end{bmatrix}$ is the
vector of unknown functions.

Based on the results in
{(a)}
and
{(b)},
write down the general solution in real-valued form.
statement_raw:
Consider the 2 x 2 system of differential equations

:<math>
\mathbf{x}'(t)=\begin{bmatrix}
-1  &  -2\\
2  &  -1
\end{bmatrix} \mathbf{x}(t)
</math>

where <math>\mathbf{x}(t)=\begin{bmatrix}x_1(t)\\x_2(t)\end{bmatrix}</math> is the vector of unknown functions.

Based on the results in [[Science:Math Exam Resources/Courses/MATH152/April 2012/Question 08 (a)|(a)]] and [[Science:Math Exam Resources/Courses/MATH152/April 2012/Question 08 (b)|(b)]], write down the general solution in real-valued form.
